urn:contentItem:5Y3F-BSC1-JBCN-435W-00000-00Nonstop election campaigns2020-01-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Nonstop election campaigns

For most Americans, conservatism basically means the stuff Republicans are for, and liberalism means whatever Democrats are for. I don’t mean this as a criticism, just a statement of fact.

One of the great things about America is that politics — never mind political philosophy — isn’t a big part of most people’s lives. Associating a body of ideas with the institutions (political parties) that are directly charged with putting ideas into action is a pragmatic way to cut to the chase. Paying attention to what the eggheads and theorists of the left and right want the parties to do is only worthwhile if you’re especially interested in politics.

The challenge for conservatives these days is that the Republican Party really doesn’t know what it’s for, beyond defending President Trump and opposing Democrats and socialism. While the fight over impeachment sucks up all of the oxygen in public, there’s a robust battle behind the scenes about what it means to be a conservative.

Some of it has spilled out into public view, usually centering on nationalism — what it means, what it requires in terms of policy, how it differs from traditional conservatism or whether it differs at all. Sens. Josh Hawley and Marco Rubio, for example, have offered thoughtful versions of “economic nationalism,” pitting it against libertarianism (both real and imagined).

There are many different schools of thought here, but a common theme is the idea that government should be more interventionist in the economy: Policymakers should be more willing to overrule the marketplace on everything from big tech to child care to trade.

Republicans were outraged by the way the Obama administration “picked winners and losers” in the economy. Some were appalled when Obama bailed out automakers with a massive handout. Trump has now given more aid to farmers than Obama ever gave Detroit, and if an elected Republican has complained about it, I missed it. In fairness, the farmer bailouts were necessitated by the president’s trade wars. But that just demonstrates Republicans’ willingness to substitute their judgment for the market’s.

There’s a cultural version of the nationalist project as well. Some conservative intellectuals — mostly, but not exclusively, Catholic — believe the state has a role in imposing its judgment in the marketplace of ideas.

I have strong views about all of this, but I thought it might be helpful to offer a few humble suggestions about how to think about such things as these debates heat up.

First, the root of conservatism is conservation. The great conservative philosopher Roger Scruton, who died earlier this month, said, “Conservatism starts from a sentiment that all mature people can readily share: the sentiment that good things are easily destroyed, but not easily created.” This sentiment is at the heart of traditional conservatism, but it’s not constrained by ideology or partisanship. Many liberals (and even some socialists) have displayed this temperament.

Second, with the great divide in conservative theory, there are those who are anti-left and those who are anti-state. For a crude illustration, some people are opposed to public schools because they don’t think education is a proper task for the state. (Milton Friedman called them “government schools.”) Others on the right think public schools are fine; they just object to how progressives operate them, filling kids’ heads with objectionable ideas.

Obviously, most libertarian purists are in the anti-state camp, but for most conservatives it’s a balancing act. A consistent conservative can be libertarian on nearly all policy questions and still favor heavily regulating or even banning pornography.

Another fault line revolves around the question, “Which state are we talking about?”

If I may show my cards a bit, outside of foreign policy, I’m very libertarian at the national level, mostly libertarian at the state level and pretty communitarian at the local level. Letting people live the way they want to live where they actually live, so long as basic civil rights are respected, has always struck me as the best way to maximize happiness and democratic accountability.

This raises a final question: Can the state actually do what you want it to do?

At the core of the conservative critique of the left has always been a basic skepticism that top-down planning from Washington can work. It used to be that the champions of such planning were mostly on the left. That’s not true any longer. And it remains to be seen whether top-down planning from the right works any better than it does from the left.

Contact Jonah Goldberg on Twitter, his handle is @JonahDispatch.

Jonah Goldberg

urn:contentItem:5VMM-T6N1-F021-620B-00000-00No one can agree how to clip Big Tech's wings and time is running out2019-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:22ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:2No one can agree how to clip Big Tech's wings and time is running outSimon Duke

The knives are out for Silicon Valley. In Washington last week Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic senator and presidential hopeful, called for a break-up of America's large technology companies. In Australia moves are afoot to create a powerful watchdog to rein in Google and Facebook. In Europe, meanwhile, America's tech giants are under continual attack for riding roughshod over competition and privacy laws.

A consensus has emerged that tighter regulation is needed to curb the excesses of Big Tech. What no one can agree on is how to clip Silicon Valley's wings.

Yesterday Jason Furman, a former chief economic adviser to President Obama, attempted to provide an answer. With Apple, Facebook, Google, Amazon and Microsoft seeking to replicate their dominance over the internet economy in artificial intelligence and other new fields, his review of the tech sector could not be more pressing.

As Mr Furman makes clear in his official report for the Treasury, the government needs to give the competition watchdog new weapons to police the digital economy. The standards used to assess technology mergers are ripe for a reboot.

The problem of curbing the big five's dominance stems from the unique dynamics of the digital economy. In areas such as internet search and social networking, the winner often takes it all. Highly efficient and innovative companies can quickly eviscerate their competitors through network effects; the more users they attract, the more data they gather, enabling them to improve their service, attract more eyeballs, and so forth.

Over time, however, such concentrations of power become a barrier to more innovative start-ups emerging. Consumers suffer, too, albeit in less overt ways than under an old-style monopolist. According to Mr Furman, we may be handing over more personal information to access "free" internet services than we would in a more competitive market.

Because most popular online services are free to consume, internet companies have been elusive prey for competition watchdogs. Proposed mergers are judged on the basis of whether prices are likely to rise because of a merger. It's tricky to prove that a merger will cause harm to consumers when personal information, not cash, is the means of exchange. According to Mr Furman, regulators use a "static and myopic" gauge to measure up technology deals.

This bias has allowed a number of deals to proceed that with the benefit of hindsight should never have been given the green light. Mr Furman is particularly critical of Facebook's $1 billion takeover of Instagram in 2012. Coupled with its 2014 swoop on WhatsApp, the company eliminated two potential threats, cementing its control over social networking. Deals of this kind are known as "killer acquisitions". For good reason.

It was once assumed that there could be no lasting monopoly in cyberspace. But this has proved wrong. Allowing tech incumbents to snuff out nascent rivals unchecked has vastly entrenched their power. Over the past decade Apple, Alphabet, Amazon, Facebook and Microsoft have bought more than 400 smaller businesses.

Clearly, takeover rules need to be overhauled so that regulators can view deals through a much wider lens. Mr Furman wants watchdogs to block acquisitions if they consider a deal would harm competition in the future, not just the present. Regulators should also consider whether a deal will cut innovation.

His proposals are radical. They would force regulators to make subjective judgments on future developments in technology, and could prevent start-up founders from selling at a time of their choosing. However, the government cannot afford to sit on its hands. Time is running out to clip Big Tech's wings.

Simon Duke is Technology Business Editor of The Times

urn:contentItem:5VMS-M0F1-DYTY-C2G2-00000-00No one can agree how to clip Big Tech's wings and time is running out2019-03-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:22ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 39No one can agree how to clip Big Tech's wings and time is running outSimon Duke

The knives are out for Silicon Valley. In Washington last week Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic senator and presidential hopeful, called for a break-up of America's large technology companies. In Australia moves are afoot to create a powerful watchdog to rein in Google and Facebook. In Europe, meanwhile, America's tech giants are under continual attack for riding roughshod over competition and privacy laws.

A consensus has emerged that tighter regulation is needed to curb the excesses of Big Tech. What no one can agree on is how to clip Silicon Valley's wings.

Yesterday Jason Furman, a former chief economic adviser to President Obama, attempted to provide an answer. With Apple, Facebook, Google, Amazon and Microsoft seeking to replicate their dominance over the internet economy in artificial intelligence and other new fields, his review of the tech sector could not be more pressing.

As Mr Furman makes clear in his official report for the Treasury, the government needs to give the competition watchdog new weapons to police the digital economy. The standards used to assess technology mergers are ripe for a reboot.

The problem of curbing the big five's dominance stems from the unique dynamics of the digital economy. In areas such as internet search and social networking, the winner often takes it all. Highly efficient and innovative companies can quickly eviscerate their competitors through network effects; the more users they attract, the more data they gather, enabling them to improve their service, attract more eyeballs, and so forth.

Over time, however, such concentrations of power become a barrier to more innovative start-ups emerging. Consumers suffer, too, albeit in less overt ways than under an old-style monopolist. According to Mr Furman, we may be handing over more personal information to access "free" internet services than we would in a more competitive market.

Because most popular online services are free to consume, internet companies have been elusive prey for competition watchdogs. Proposed mergers are judged on the basis of whether prices are likely to rise because of a merger. It's tricky to prove that a merger will cause harm to consumers when personal information, not cash, is the means of exchange. According to Mr Furman, regulators use a "static and myopic" gauge to measure up technology deals.

This bias has allowed a number of deals to proceed that with the benefit of hindsight should never have been given the green light. Mr Furman is particularly critical of Facebook's $1 billion takeover of Instagram in 2012. Coupled with its 2014 swoop on WhatsApp, the company eliminated two potential threats, cementing its control over social networking. Deals of this kind are known as "killer acquisitions". For good reason.

It was once assumed that there could be no lasting monopoly in cyberspace. But this has proved wrong. Allowing tech incumbents to snuff out nascent rivals unchecked has vastly entrenched their power. Over the past decade Apple, Alphabet, Amazon, Facebook and Microsoft have bought more than 400 smaller businesses.

Clearly, takeover rules need to be overhauled so that regulators can view deals through a much wider lens. Mr Furman wants watchdogs to block acquisitions if they consider a deal would harm competition in the future, not just the present.

Regulators should also consider whether a deal will cut innovation.

His proposals are radical. They would force regulators to make subjective judgments on future developments in technology, and could prevent start-up founders from selling at a time of their choosing. However, the government cannot afford to sit on its hands. Time is running out to clip Big Tech's wings.

Simon Duke is Technology Business Editor of The Times

urn:contentItem:5XN8-WMK1-DYTY-C06K-00000-00'No party is championing innovation and that is wrong';Firms in Cambridge's tech hub fear election will bring policies that stifle growth, writes Hannah Boland What business wants2019-12-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:22ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 8'No party is championing innovation and that is wrong'Firms in Cambridge's tech hub fear election will bring policies that stifle growth, writes Hannah Boland What business wantsHannah Boland

Andy Richards makes an unintelligible noise; a pained stream of vowels that sound somewhere between a sigh and a groan. "That's despair," he laughs.

Richards is an optimist. The biotech entrepreneur should be with his track record, having helped to build reams of successful life sciences businesses. However, even he can't muster enthusiasm about the election.

"Like many people, I've become disillusioned with politics over the last few years," he shrugs. "It's sort of sad."

Across Cambridge, a hub for the UK's brightest technology and life sciences companies, there is a similar frustration - a murmuring sense of disaffection.

Another election isn't exactly what they want. "It's almost like a double negative," AstraZeneca's Andy Williams explains. "Basically it just gets in the way of business continuity and [brings] potential uncertainty."

Among research institutes, he says, there is a "nervousness rather than actual negativity at the moment".

Nervousness, of course, because an election brings with it uncertainty. But, this time around, it's more than that. The technology industry is estimated to bring in more than £180bn to the UK economy, life sciences around £30bn, and both create jobs at a rate which outstrips many other sectors. And yet, it appears "there isn't a natural ally necessarily anywhere in the political spectrum at the moment", Edward Benthall, chairman of Cambridge venture firm Cambridge Innovation Capital, says.

Brexit is a major sticking point. Prior to the referendum almost 90pc of the tech sector was opposed to leaving the EU, and concerns over how the life sciences supply chain will function has weighed heavy on pharmaceutical companies. Almost three quarters of Cambridge voters also wanted to remain in the EU in 2016.

For some, it is entirely dictating their vote. "The main problem is what type of Brexit, if any, we get," says Hermann Hauser, partner at venture firm Amadeus Capital Partners. "If the outcome was another referendum, I think that would improve things enormously. From a commercial point of view, that is by far the most desirable outcome."

But, outside of Brexit, there are other, equally uncomfortable choicesROSE to be made.

"There isn't really a party that champions wealth creation through innovation, and that does feel a bit awkward," says Benthall. "I can't quite believe that any of the parties really would see the growth of jobs and value that happens around Cambridge as anything other than a good thing, but for some reason, it doesn't seem easy for them to champion that case."

More widely, there have been major pushes from both sides of the political debate to take on big tech - plans for digital services taxes on US giants, or to make the Silicon Valley firms pay for a part-nationalisation of BT.

But closer to home, British companies are warning that there are policies across the board which could affect their ability to innovate, and prove potential roadblocks for growth.

One area of concern is around entrepreneurs' relief - a tax break which reduces the amount of capital gains tax that business owners have to pay when they sell a business.

According to their manifestos, if the Labour Party or the Liberal Democrats come into power, the relief will be scrapped. If the Conservatives do, a "review and reform" is planned.

And, yet, while there appears cross-party backing of some change to the tax break, doing so could be "pretty damaging" for innovators, says Benthall. "It's much harder to start a new company than it is to work for an existing incumbent player, so they deserve the relief that they get and that needs to be maintained."

Stephen Chandler, a former entrepreneur who is now at venture capital firm Notion Capital, agrees. "Whilst I'm open to tightening requirements to ensure it does what was intended, anything that curtails entrepreneurial risk appetite ... is a negative in my view."

There are other policies on the table which are causing some concern - Labour's plans to establish a "generic drug company", for example, has prompted alarm within the life sciences sector. How it would work, the party says, is that if companies did not set "fair prices" for patented drugs, the UK would then be able to secure access to generic versions of those drugs through things such as research exemptions.

This could prove "very dangerous," says Richards. The UK is a "very small part of the pharmaceuticals market", and establishing a new generics company "would rip up global international trade positions in intellectual property".

A particular priority "for life sciences research and industry development, is the commercialisation of intellectual property", says Alan Hirzel, the boss of London-listed Abcam. It creates an environment where there are clusters of spin-out companies from universities, essential for the next generation of commercial talent.

"We'd like to keep that kind of environment here," says Hirzel.

Ultimately keeping the status quo is high on the list of demands of many of the companies in the region.

In recent years, a succession of major initiatives, such as the Industrial Strategy, has proven hugely beneficial to a host of companies across the technology and life sciences industries, not only in helping to foster innovation, but then in propelling them into the public sphere.

Specific sector deals for artificial intelligence, life sciences and automotive have led to more taxpayer cash being funnelled into companies developing ground-breaking technology. Alongside that, businesses have flourished in Cambridge.

Data from Centre for Cities indicates that the city has the highest proportion of patent applications for the residents who live there, and is now home to six billion-dollar companies.

Last year, almost £500m was invested by venture capitalists into Cambridge-based businesses, and as well as attracting giants AstraZeneca, Microsoft and Amazon, there are thousands of exciting smaller companies dotted around the city.

"It's about preserving what we've got," says Clive Morris, the boss of liquid biopsy firm Inivata.

He says he doesn't really mind who wins the election - "as long as they're accommodating to life sciences".

In fact, taking a hands-off approach could be the best solution for a future government, some say.

"Let those of us who want to build businesses in the UK get on with it," urges Martin Frost, the boss of CMR Surgical, a robotics business which recently became a "unicorn", valued at more than $1bn. "Technology needs, I would say, little government and few rules."

Where rules could, perhaps, be the most damaging would be on immigration, which is a major part of both the life sciences and technology sector. Around 45pc of the UK tech sector's net employment growth is made up of workers from overseas and there have been warnings that tougher regulation of immigration could worsen skill shortages in life science.

"Silicon Valley wealth was created through immigration to California," Frost says. "It would be disappointing if we were to become more monoculture."

Perhaps equally challenging would be any pressure on R&D funding - although, so far, this is a point on which many of the parties are united. "Labour will create an innovation nation," the party said, tabling plans to hike direct support for R&D and better "crowd in" private investment.

The Conservatives, meanwhile, are looking to set up a new funding agency, styled in the fashion of Washington's Darpa. They've pledged to continue to work with the EU on scientific research, including Horizon - the EU's main research programme which has been at the centre of much concern by start-ups.

Taking into account questions over Brexit, immigration, tax changes and any R&D policies, what becomes clear is that this is an election which could upend the life sciences and technology industries.

There is an "awful lot" that needs to be resolved, CIC's Benthall says. Not only is it "very unclear what the outcome is going to be, but it's also quite unclear what happens in any of the possible outcomes".

Whilst it is apparent this is viewed as a hugely important vote, many in the city don't really know what to think. "I'm interested, engaged, a bit anxious... but mostly a bit confused probably," says Benthall. "It really matters. And it matters a lot to what's going on here in Cambridge."

urn:contentItem:5X1D-STP1-JB5M-W3NF-00000-00No plans for a legislation on regulating social media companies: Ravi Shankar Prasad2019-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:22ZLexisNexisNo plans for a legislation on regulating social media companies: Ravi Shankar PrasadSoumyarendra Barik

Is the government considering a legislation to regulate social media companies, to prevent them from curbing the rights of lakhs of persons supporting nationalistic ideology, asked BJP MP R.K. Sinha in the Rajya Sabha on July 11. In response, IT Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said that the government was not planning to bring any legislation to regulate social media companies, and that the "Government is fully committed to freedom of speech and expression and privacy of its citizens as enshrined in the constitution of India".



Prasad added that the "government does not monitor content appearing on [the] internet" and it is in fact law enforcement agencies who take action against "malicious content" on the internet on a "case-to-case basis". He also said that under the IT Act, 2000, social media companies are intermediaries. Under section 79 of the Act, "intermediaries are required to disable/remove unlawful content on being notified by appropriate government or its agency", he said, before adding:

"The Information Technology (Intermediaries Guidelines) Rules 2011 notified under this section require that the intermediaries shall observe due diligence while discharging their duties and shall inform the users not to host, display, upload, modify, publish, transmit, update or share any information that is harmful, objectionable, and unlawful in any way." - Ravi Shankar Prasad

Big Tech's repeated run-ins with Indian government on 'safeguarding citizens' rights'

* The Ministry of Home Affairs, in November 2018, had said that Twitter had been slow in removing or blocking objectionable content in some cases. It said that compliance for removal of such content had been 60%, even when the competent authority issued an order to Twitter.

* In February 2019, Twitter was summoned by a Parliamentary Standing Committee on Information Technology to examine "how to safeguard citizens' rights on social/online news media platforms". This meeting was called a day after there were protests outside Twitter India's office accusing the platform of being "biased against the right-wing". However, Twitter didn't appear for the parliamentary hearing.

* In February 2019, a Parliamentary Committee on Information Technology had also called on Facebook, WhatsApp and Instagram representatives to discuss safeguarding citizens' rights on online platforms in the same month.

Nordic competition authorities on Monday pushed for the European Union's antitrust enforcers to consider adopting their antitrust rules so the enforcers can address competition issues surrounding digital platforms that would typically fly under the radar. ...

Nordic competition authorities on Monday pushed for the European Union's antitrust enforcers to consider adopting their antitrust rules so the enforcers can address competition issues surrounding digital platforms that would typically fly under the radar. In a joint memorandum, the competition enforcers of Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden all raised concerns about so-called killer acquisitions, or small deals that big tech companies use to nip the threat of up-and-coming rivals in the bud. While these deals typically fall below merger reporting requirements, the memo pointed out that the competition laws of Norway, Sweden and Iceland allow them to catch these acquisitions as they happen. "In Norway, Sweden and Iceland, the power to order the notification of mergers that fall below the notification thresholds can be employed when there are reasonable grounds to assume that competition will be affected by the transaction," the memo read. The countries pointed out that in Norway, competition officials can also impose disclosure requirements on individual firms. The disclosures and the merger notifications would help officials keep abreast of mergers that fall below traditional merger notification thresholds and fill any enforcement gaps, according to the memo. "We suggest that the European Commission considers the introduction of supplementary tools," the memo read. "In this context, the set of tools in the Nordic countries may serve as an inspiration, both at the EU level and at the member state level." The memo also noted the European Commission's efforts to increase regulations on entities acting as "gatekeepers" in the digital space. The countries pushed the commission to take a "harmonized approach," like including other member states in the process and ensuring compatibility with competition rules, to "avoid fragmentation and safeguard the effective functioning of digital markets." "An EU-wide process will guarantee a higher level of harmonization and transparency, which are crucial for preserving a level playing field on the single market and for legal certainty and predictability," the memo read. The Nordic countries also said the commission should establish a "clear and objective set of criteria" on who will be considered "digital gatekeepers," so companies are aware of what kind of regulations they'll be subject to. As the commission considers other changes to laws that would allow it to intervene in markets where certain companies become too dominant, the memo advocated for companies at the other end of these proposed rule changes to have proper protections. More specifically, the Nordic countries called for companies to have the "right to judicial review" and other "procedural safeguards" in the face of a potential increase in the European Commission's regulatory power. They also stressed "transparent and predictable rules" within these rule changes to "ensure legal certainty and predictability, preserve incentives to invest and innovate, and ensure the effective use of" the changes. The European Commission did not immediately respond to requests for comment Monday. --Additional reporting by Bryan Koenig and Matthew Perlman. Editing by Adam LoBelia.

urn:contentItem:5XFT-5FH1-DYDW-71T4-00000-00No reasonable person would ever call Apple a monopoly, says CEO Tim Cook2019-11-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:22ZLexisNexisNo reasonable person would ever call Apple a monopoly, says CEO Tim CookNew Delhi, 2019-11-08 14:38:42

November 08 -- Apple CEO Tim Cook is on a tour in Europe. After having enjoyed some German beer at the ongoing Oktoberfest in Munich, Cook has made his way to Berlin. While visiting a Berlin-based startup called Blinkist, which summarises non-fiction books in an easy-to-consume interface, Cook spoke about Apple's pricing strategy, its bet on video streaming services and much more.


Speaking to German magazine Stern, Cook said that Apple always tries to price its services and devices as low as possible. Yes, many may scoff at that statement considering the stratospheric pricing of its flagship smartphones. With the iPhone 11 series though, Apple has indeed priced the base iPhone 11 at a price lower than what the iPhone XR had launched at. The iPhone 11 Pro and iPhone 11 Pro Max prices are similar to the prices of the iPhone XS and iPhone XS Max. Not to mention the affordable pricing of Apple Arcade in India at Rs 99 per month and the plan to offer free Apple TV+ streaming service for a year for anyone who buys a new Apple product this year.
"We always try to keep our prices as low as possible. Fortunately, we were able to lower the price of the iPhone this year," said Cook.
 
 
On the topic of taking a 30 percent cut in the sale of paid apps and the accusations of Apple being a monopoly by trying to push its own apps on the App Store, Cook said that he found this accusation outlandish.
"No sane person would ever call Apple a monopoly," said Cook to Stern. He also mentioned that every market that Apple operated in has stiff competition. Sweden-based music streaming company Spotify would not really agree with that. In fact, Spotify even filed a complaint with the EU antitrust regulators against Apple, saying the iPhone maker unfairly limited rivals to its own Apple Music streaming service.
While Cook didn't comment on the Spotify fiasco, he views the App Store as the only channel to sell iOS apps as an advantage. He said that the App Store provides a trustworthy environment to purchase apps. "We ensure that every app that we curate is checked thoroughly," said Cook.
 
Cook also elaborated on how the company is looking at its services segment as the next growth story. "My assessment is that Apple would achieve even faster growth with new services in the coming year, with projected revenue of $46 to $50 bn this year," said Cook. Speaking about Apple TV+, Cook said that he didn't think Netflix would be a competition and the video-streaming segment had space for many players of which Apple TV+ was one.
On the topic of US Presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren's call for breaking up Big Tech, Cook said that he has always been in favour of investigating big companies and has no problem with that.
 
Blinkist which boasts of about 500,000 paying subscribers from across the world, focusses on giving you the key takeaways from non-fiction tomes in 15 minutes. Cook highlighted how startups such as Blinkist were a prime example of modern firms, which could be set up in one part of the world and have customers all over the world.

Good morning. This is your CQ Cyber newsletter for Friday, May 29, 2020.

TOPLINES

1. Trump's social media order not liked nor shared: Opposition to (and skepticism of) President Trump's executive order threatening online immunity for social media companies was swift and bipartisan.

2. Overhauling emerging tech research: A group of lawmakers led by Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer wants to change the way the government fosters emerging technology.

3. ACLU files facial surveillance suit: The organization is suing the controversial facial recognition company Clearview AI in Illinois, arguing that its data gathering violates privacy rights.

4. Cyber crooks on the coronavirus prowl: Google's Threat Analysis Group has observed an uptick in activity by Indian hackers-for-hire carrying out phishing attacks by posing as health officials.

FULL BRIEFING

1. Trump's executive order to curb social media greeted with bipartisan skepticism

Even before it was signed Thursday, President Donald Trump's executive order encouraging federal regulators to reconsider legal immunity for social media companies was pilloried by a diverse coalition of opponents who questioned the order's legality and Trump's motivations.

The order, signed by Trump on the heels of a multiday online tirade aimed at Twitter after the company fact-checked a pair of the president's tweets about mail-in voting, would direct federal agencies to reexamine Section 230 of the 1996 Communications Decency Act.

Section 230, which prevents online publishers -- including companies such as Twitter and Facebook -- from being sued over third-party content posted on their websites, is a prized liability shield for Silicon Valley that experts have credited with playing a crucial role in fostering the growth of the internet as a bastion of free speech and expression.

But Trump and his allies, who have accused Big Tech platforms of censoring conservative viewpoints on their sites, have long considered changes to Section 230 as a way of exerting pressure on the companies.

"A small handful of powerful social media monopolies controls a vast portion of all public and private communications in the United States," Trump said before signing the order. "They've had unchecked power to censor, restrict, edit, shape, hide, alter virtually any form of communication between private citizens and public audiences."

Trump was joined in the Oval Office by Attorney General William Barr, who said Section 230 "has been stretched way beyond its original intent."

Specifically, the executive order directs the Commerce Department to ask the Federal Communications Commission, an independent agency, to propose new regulations clarifying actions by online publishers that might violate Section 230. The order also directs the Federal Trade Commission to review thousands of complaints of online censorship submitted to the White House by the public.

The order also asks federal agencies to enumerate and report to the White House Office of Management and Budget on how much they are spending on social media. And it tasks Barr to work with state authorities to see if social media platforms are engaging in any unfair and deceptive acts or practices that may violate state laws.

See my complete report on reaction to Trump's executive order here.

2. Bipartisan bill seeks to counter China on emerging technology

Lawmakers from both parties, including Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer, D-N.Y., on Wednesday announced legislation that would overhaul the government's research and development approach to emerging technology with the aim of countering a push by China for innovation dominance this century.

The bicameral legislation (S 3832, HR 6978) would rechristen the National Science Foundation as the National Science and Technology Foundation and authorize $100 billion for a new directorate within the agency to fund research and development in 10 areas of emerging technology the lawmakers believe "will define global competitiveness" in the coming decades.

The fields of technology covered under the legislation range from familiar topics -- artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, robotics and automation and advanced telecommunications -- to more obscure ones like biotechnology and genomics, quantum computing and semiconductors, according to a summary of the legislation.

The newly created directorate would be authorized to use the $100 billion to increase funding for partnerships between research universities and the private sector and educational benefits including undergraduate scholarships, industry training programs and post-doctoral support.

The agency could also use the funding to "facilitate and accelerate the transfer of new technologies from the lab to the marketplace, including expanding access to investment capital" and coordinate with state officials and private companies to build "regional innovation ecosystems," according to the summary.

The bill would authorize an additional $10 billion for the Commerce Department to designate 10 new regional technology hubs and help state and local officials "connect disadvantaged populations and places to new job and business opportunities developing key technologies."

Schumer and the other lawmakers backing the legislation -- Sen. Todd Young, R-Ind., Rep. Ro Khanna, D-Calif., and Rep. Mike Gallagher, R-Wis. -- describe it as a push to reverse eroding American leadership in innovation that could be further exacerbated by the effects of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

"The coronavirus pandemic has shown the science and technology gap between the United States and the rest of the world is closing fast and that threatens our long-term health, economic competitiveness, and national security," Schumer said in a statement. "America cannot afford to continue our decades-long underinvestment and expect to lead the world."

Young accused the Chinese government of using the moment to get ahead of other countries "by virtue of being the first to emerge on the other side of this pandemic.''

"Instead of allowing Beijing to threaten our values and interests, now is the time for America to invest in ourselves and give the world a clear alternative," Young said in a statement.

Read my full report on the emerging technology legislation here.

3. ACLU sues facial recognition company Clearview AI, alleging privacy violations

The American Civil Liberties Union is suing the controversial facial recognition firm Clearview AI, which has amassed a biometric database of millions of American faces, over concerns that the company violated the privacy of individuals in Illinois who did not consent to their inclusion in the software.

The lawsuit, filed Thursday in the Cook County Circuit Court, alleges that Clearview AI is in violation of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, which requires companies that gather biometric information -- such as facial scans -- to notify people and obtain individual consent.

The suit could grow into a landmark case over the use of facial recognition technology in the United States, which is being debated at every level of government.

"Companies like Clearview will end privacy as we know it, and must be stopped," said Nathan Freed Wessler, an ACLU senior staff attorney. "This menacing technology gives governments, companies, and individuals the unprecedented power to spy on us wherever we go -- tracking our faces at protests, Alcoholics Anonymous meetings, political rallies, places of worship, and more."

Clearview AI did not respond to a request for comment.

4. "Hackers-for-hire" are posing as health officials to steal login info, Google says

Google is tracking an increase in activity by "hackers-for-hire" who are using the COVID-19 pandemic to try and steal Google account credentials, the company's Threat Analysis Group said.

The latest hacking attempts, which are mostly originating in India, are part of "a resurgence in COVID-related hacking and phishing attempts from numerous commercial and government-backed attackers," the company said in a blog post on Wednesday.

The attacks out of India involve posing as an official with the World Health Organization and have targeted financial services, consulting and health care corporations in the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada and other countries, Google said.

"The lures themselves encourage individuals to sign up for direct notifications from the WHO to stay informed of COVID-19 related announcements, and link to attacker-hosted websites that bear a strong resemblance to the official WHO website, Google said.

"The sites typically feature fake login pages that prompt potential victims to give up their Google account credentials, and occasionally encourage individuals to give up other personal information, such as their phone numbers."

urn:contentItem:5FFR-CKX1-JB20-G0KF-00000-00Norfolk Southern Corp at JPMorgan Aviation, Transportation & Industrials Conference - Final2015-03-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:22ZLexisNexis030415a5630324.724Norfolk Southern Corpat JPMorgan Aviation, Transportation & Industrials Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* James Squire

Norfolk Southern Corporation- President

Conference Call Participants

* Brian Ossenbeck

J.P.Morgan - Analyst

Presentation

BRIAN OSSENBECK, ANALYST, J.P.MORGAN: Okay. Up next we have Jim Squire. This slide says President, but soon we'll be adding CEO to that as of June 1 -- from Norfolk Southern. We're really happy to have him here today, along with Katie Cook from Investor Relations. Again, my name is Brian Ossenbeck. I cover the transports here at J.P.Morgan. And Jim's going to go over a few slides and we'll kick it off with Q&A. So please, Jim, take it away.

JAMES SQUIRE, PRESIDENT, NORFOLK SOUTHERN CORPORATION: Thank you, and thank you, everyone, for coming. First, the obligatory legal disclaimer. Let me remind you that during this presentation, I'll make certain forward-looking statements. And these are all subject to risks and uncertainties, of course, and our actual results may differ materially from those projected.

And I would invite you to refer to our annual and quarterly reports filed with the SEC for a full discussion of all the risk factors and uncertainties we view as important.

So thanks again for coming, everyone. On behalf of all of us at Norfolk Southern, I appreciate this opportunity very much to tell you about our Company. I would like to start with an overview of some guiding principles. And following that, I'll review our recent financial performance and give you some color on the current state of our railroad and our outlook for 2015.

So let's begin with the franchise. Let's see here; here we go. Our railroad connects businesses to the marketplaces of the world, and we are a safe, efficient and dependable transporter of raw materials, intermediate and finished goods for all manners of shippers and receivers.

Our network covers most of the eastern US, 20,000 route miles in 22 states as shown here. We connect efficiently with all the other major rail carriers. We serve the major population centers in the United States. We view our mission as facilitating international trade as well via every major seaport on the East Coast of the US, 10 river ports and 9 lake ports.

We operate the most extensive intermodal network in the eastern US, which generated half of our 2014 volume. And we are a major transporter of industrial products, coal, agricultural commodities and finished automobiles.

Our vision is straightforward. We strive to be the safest, most customer-focused and successful transportation company in the world. And to accomplish this, we follow five guiding principles. First, we strive to deliver safe, reliable, efficient service that allows us to grow volume and raise prices by creating value for customers.

We aim to grow volume because ours is a substantially fixed-cost franchise in which additional business naturally comes at declining marginal cost. So therein lies the logic for a volume growth strategy financially.

We seek to raise prices and revenue per unit to compensate for high embedded labor expenses in our business and otherwise offset inflation. And of course, the key to both volume growth and price increases over time is providing excellent service.

The second principle -- we use existing resources whenever we can to maximize incremental margin from volume growth. And although we invest for growth, we recognize that freight, that shares, in-place infrastructure is prima facie, preferable to freight demanding new or specialized facilities.

Third, we spend to replenish essential railroad assets, things like track, roadway structure, signal systems, locomotives, freight cars. We try to resist the temptation to cut spending on these things at low points in the business cycle or to divert spending beyond them at high points, because thriving in our business, we believe, depends on an abiding commitment to core CapEx.

Fourth, we return ample funds to shareholders. Having seen the resiliency of our cash flow through the great recession, we and our shareholders believe that our balance sheet can support reasonable leverage, do supplement distributions from free cash flow. So that's certainly a key principle for us as well.

And lastly, while opportunities for M&A in a mature, heavily regulated industry like ours are necessarily somewhat limited, there are times when it makes sense to buy or sell assets around the core franchise. So our recent acquisition of lines from CP, the D&H South, are a great example of that. The lines fit perfectly within our existing operation. In fact, we're the main user of them today.

So there's little, if any, execution risk from the transaction. And moreover, since we're tying together parts of our network, the synergies, which we predict, should be readily obtainable.

Now, these five principles have contributed to our Company's success over the year s and drove record results in 2014. For the year, we delivered best-ever financial records across the board, including a 3% increase to $11.6 billion in revenue, which translated to a 10% increase in income from operations and our first-ever operating ratio below 70.

Net income and EPS were up 8% and 9% respectively, excluding a gain from selling property in 2013.

Record revenue marked the fourth consecutive $11 billion-plus year for us and the diversity of our franchise propelled overall network volume upwards by 5%, notwithstanding softness in our coal sector.

With respect to capital allocation, we raised our quarterly dividend by 10% and reached 130 consecutive quarters of paying dividends on our common stock. We invested $318 million in share repurchases, while continuing to fund core infrastructure and capabilities to enhance performance and growth and value creation in the future.

These accomplishments are a testament to our people, who were able to overcome significant operating and service challenges in 2014, brought on by a harsh winter and a surge of freight volume. And while we were pleased with our financial results, our service did not meet all of our customers' expectations. So we've been taking steps to improve service by investing in people, equipment and infrastructure.

These additional resources will help foster the level of service our customers expect and deserve. By November of last year, we had resources in place -- again, people, equipment and infrastructure -- to reset our network, yielding sequential improvements in train speed and terminal dwell, in December, which we maintained into January of this year.

Over the last couple of weeks, winter weather in the eastern US, our territory has those challenges. And as a result, we've seen a downturn in our most recent service metrics. But even so, with the benefit of the additional crews, locomotives and infrastructure that came onboard in late 2014, plus continued hiring that is front-end loaded for 2015, we expect to see service improve in the second quarter and during the remainder of the year.

All total, the slower network and difficult weather of 2014 did add about $130 million to our cost structure last year. And as we realized the benefits of the investment we have made, are able to increase system velocity later this year, we'll start to see those costs come down.

The volume this year in 2015 started out strong, although we did see a dip in the recent 2 weeks' car loadings. That's largely reflective of the weather, we believe, and not inherently lower demand.

Similar to last year, we are seeing continued growth year-over-year in our chemicals and metals and construction lines of business, which were up 10% and 6% year-to-date respectively. This is related largely to energy-driven demand, such as crude by rail and frack sand as well as aggregates and coiled steel.

Intermodal volume was up 4%, reflecting increases in international demand, a function in part of traffic diverted onto our network from the West Coast. Plus, continued strength in our domestic intermodal market as motor carrier capacity limitations continue to support the intermodal value proposition.

As we look to the remainder of the year, we anticipate opportunities for volume growth across most of our business units. Crude by rail and Marcellus and Utica shale inputs and outputs will benefit 2015, albeit probably at a moderated growth rate.

Now, to provide some context, our 2014 crude by rail volumes were 113,000 carloads, were about 1.5% of our total carloads, up 50% though compared with 2013. Similarly, the Marcellus and Utica inputs and outputs comprised about 1.6% of our volumes and also experienced strong growth in 2014.

We anticipate higher steel volumes to support commercial construction and automotive sectors. Increased road construction will boost aggregate and asphalt volume while growth in housing starts will generate growth in lumber and construction materials.

Our automotive volumes are expected to increase with vehicle production at several key Norfolk Southern-served plants. And within our agricultural markets, we expect increased soybean and higher ethanol and feed shipments.

Intermodal will benefit from a consumer-driven economy and capacity constraints in the truck market that continue to support highway conversions in our domestic business. And international demand should benefit from new customers and service offerings.

Coal is an exception to our growth outlook, as volumes should be lower in both the utility and export markets. Utility demand will reflect lower natural gas prices, while global oversupply, low prices and the strong US dollar will leave US coal producers at a disadvantage in the world market.

As background, coal was approximately 17% of our volume last year and 2014 volumes declined about 5% versus the prior year. With regarding to pricing, we expect higher market demand relative to tight capacity that will support core price increases with the exception of coal, which we expect to be flat.

Now, based on the current outlook for lower fuel prices, our 2015 fuel surcharge revenue will decrease substantially to less than half of the $1.3 billion we generated in 2014 in FSC revenue. About half of that 2014 FSC revenue was from contracts linked to WTI and about half was from contracts linked on highway diesel.

About two-thirds of that WTI-based revenue was from contracts with triggers at or above $64 per barrel. So those contracts will yield no fuel surcharge revenue this year at current prices. And the remaining contracts will generate substantially lower revenue.

As the fuel surcharge contracts roll over, over time, we intend to move away from WTI, when it is constructive to do so, to more closely align our surcharge program with on-highway diesel prices.

So in summary, the year holds opportunities for growth across most of our franchise in terms of both volume and core pricing. But we will also see decreased coal volume and fuel surcharge revenue.

Now, let's take a look at expenses. We expect our fuel costs to decrease significantly, of course, partly offsetting the impact of lower FSC revenue. In addition, some of the service related cost will decline, as network velocity picks up in the second half.

The impact of the hiring I mentioned should be front-end loaded in 2015, as will the impact of increased wage costs effective January 1 this year versus prior years where the increases took effect as of July 1. So as a result, about two-thirds of the $85 million increase in wage costs in 2015 will occur in the first half of the year.

And in addition, we have about $11 million of cost in the first quarter of this year related to a new agreement, an on-property agreement, with the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Trainmen. That's a contract signing bonus and a similar lump-sum payment will be recorded in the fourth quarter for employees with active service during the year.

This is a productivity enhancing agreement, we believe. So over time, we should see offsets to those expenses and more from work rules changes we were able to negotiate with the BLE.

Now, given our outlook for the year and our firm balance sheet, we're well positioned to strike the right balance, we believe, between reinvesting in the franchise and returning significant funds to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases.

We have $2.4 billion committed in our capital budget. About 70% of that is core franchise investment. About $220 million is for the federally mandated (inaudible) project and the remaining 20% of CapEx will support growth and productivity initiatives.

In addition to those investments, our board has approved a $0.02 per share, 4% increase in our quarterly dividend, effective for dividends paid this quarter. And in 2015, we anticipate returning about $1 billion to shareholders through share buybacks.

We have 2015 year marked for the acquisition of the Delaware and Hudson assets from Canadian Pacific, which as I mentioned, should be a great bolt-on to our existing network.

So thanks for the opportunity to discuss Norfolk Southernwith you today. I want to highlight that our franchise is diverse and wide-reaching. We're committed to maintaining safety, reliability and efficiency across all of our lines of business.

Our 2014 financial performance was record-breaking and we'll build on that momentum moving forward. Our 2015 growth prospects are favorable for most of our markets and we are fully committed to improving customer service. And most important I think are the principles that have guided our accomplishments to this point.

We have a strong record of success and look forward to building on the Norfolk Southernlegacy. We're confident we are the right steps to continue creating value for our customers in the communities we serve, the employees of this Company and of course, for our shareholders. So thank you for your attention. I'd be happy to answer any questions.

Questions and Answers

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Okay. Thank you, Jim. Just looking at the first quarter, we're about two-thirds of the way through. Clearly, all the puts and takes there, as you look at international divergence from the intermodal side and you see coal down about 7%, I believe it was.

So can you just fill in the blanks for the rest of the quarter? Where do you think the quarter could end up on a year-over-year basis in terms of just volume? And what are the puts and takes that could potentially move it one way or another?

JAMES SQUIRE: Okay. As you said, volumes for the quarter to date, up about 2%, pretty broad-based strength in the industrial products and automotive volumes, IP up 5%. Tracking the types of growth rates we were seeing last year for most of the year, a little bit of muted growth in the intermodal segment because of weather primarily, and some ripple effects from the West Coast port shutdown.

Coal is the soft spot, down 7%. Some of that is weather related. I would say this about the volume trends so far this year. I think that the effects, the trend, over the last couple of weeks is probably not indicative. We've seen a sharp downturn in railcar loadings across the industry the last few weeks.

I attribute that to weather. I think that we'll see a snap-back in volumes as we move through the rest of March and into the second quarter like we saw last year. So I read the volume for the year-to-date as indicative of a pretty strong underlying economy still there.

I think the intermodal volumes will rebound to growth rates like we saw last year, high-single-digits, that type of thing. And they'll be both domestic and international. Coal is the wild card. We are expecting lower coal shipments in both the utility and the export segment this year.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Okay. On the international intermodal, do you think these are just diversions that were built up after the labor issues out on the West Coast, or are these more share gains that you think you could potentially hang onto for the longer term like we saw back in 2002?

With the lockout, there was a fair amount of traffic that moved away from those ports and just stayed there. So is the network set up to take those? Are there any areas you feel that's a little more sticky in terms of the volumes that could potentially be coming your way?

JAMES SQUIRE: We did see some temporary diversion. So for sure, that has bumped up international shipments in the short term, and these are vessels that were rerouted en route. And some of that will revert back to the West Coast ports for sure. So I'd say that, yes, we certainly have seen some diversions in the short run.

Longer term, I believe many of our ocean carrier customers are interested in East Coast ports. We've seen strong growth in East coast ports really dating back a year, a year and a half. As the labor situation started to develop, we were getting more and more interest on the part of our customers in East Coast work callings.

So the East Coast ports have a real opportunity right now to hold onto some of that volume that has been diverted. They are investing for that. We have the service offerings in place. We've got great coverage from all of the East Coast ports. So we can really make hay with that.

The question is East Coast port capacity and whether there is sufficient capacity today to really take on large-scale diversions from the West Coast. I'm not sure we have that type of capacity on the East Coast. We have some room to grow. We'll hold onto some of the diverted business and then it's a question of investment and increases in capacity going forward.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Okay. So it sounds like the longer term growth would still take a little bit of investment on the port side to really see differentials there.

JAMES SQUIRE: I would say so and I think it'll happen, it'll happen.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Right.

JAMES SQUIRE: All the ports are doing that; it's just a question of time.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Okay. Then just more broadly on intermodal, clearly, you have the quarters over -- as you mentioned, over half the volumes last year were from intermodal. Can you just give us an update on where the utilization of the quarters are and how you think of just balancing the network? Is intermodal something you want to take to 55%, 60%?

As coal continues to shrink, perhaps that'll just grow naturally in terms of the mix. So clearly, there's a lot of factors in intermodal when you think about getting the round trip, getting the density, serving all the customers efficiently. So maybe you can just give us an update on where you are now and how you see that engine which has been so good for the Company, in a couple of years' time?

JAMES SQUIRE: Sure. First, the question of capacity in our intermodal network in particular, we have invested pretty heavily in the last 5 to 10 years in creating additional capacity through new terminals, greenfield terminals and line of road capacity improvements as well. So we're in a very good position in terms of capacity utilization today, with room, lots of room to grow.

So our strategy henceforth in terms of growth capacity and investment in the intermodal business will be to utilize the existing resources, as I emphasized in my opening comments. We're really determined to fill up the capacity that we have created to lean into pricing a little bit more, particularly in that business, to complete the value proposition that we have created in domestic intermodal through the investments that we have made.

And I think there's tremendous opportunity in the volume growth still to come in that business from additional incremental margin and utilization drawing on the operating leverage that we have created for that business. So very excited about that.

Our highest incremental margin business is actually our general merchandise portfolio of businesses because you put another car onto a scheduled train and it comes at very low marginal cost. So we'd love to grow those businesses too. And those are, to some extent, reflective of what the economy gives us, but we are certainly all about growing our merchandise franchise too, thus, the investments in the Bellevue classification yard, which we highlighted in our Investor Day this year. That creates capacity for those businesses that utilize the fixed-cost network and a great opportunity for leverage there as the economy grows into it.

Coal faces a number of challenges this year. And certainly, the utility coal volumes with gas trading below $3 will take a step down. The last time we've seen natural gas in that price range was in 2012 and sure enough, volumes were down. Utility coal volumes were down significantly that year versus the prior year, 2011.

And we're likely to see that this year as well. The utilities have become adept at substituting gas for coal and switching back and forth as conditions warrant. There is a floor there and gas prices have been volatile over the years. We are confident that we will see a rebound in gas prices eventually. Supply will come out; demand will increase, as always happens. So eventually, we'll see a rebalancing and our coal volumes will in turn rebound.

A different dynamic on the export side, but the same result. There, it's not about substituting other energy sources. It's about oversupply in the global marketplace and weakening demand globally. US producers, with that said, have been very resilient and continuing to send coal into the global marketplace. And we're continuing to see coal move over our export terminal.

We're primarily a Met franchise in Hampton Road. So although it's been soft the last couple of weeks, we will continue to ship some, and our customers will ship some volumes into the international market. Prices seem to have stabilized there somewhat, so we're not seeing further pressure on prices on our producers. But that's it; it'll be challenging.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: You mentioned it's soft the last couple -- is that because of the weather, because I believe you had a couple of days we had to shut actually down the facility there.

JAMES SQUIRE: For sure. And as I said, really the volume trend in the last few weeks to me is attributable to the weather. It gets very difficult and we've talked about weather ad nauseam and you're tired of hearing about it and I'm tired of talking about it. But unfortunately, it's that time of year.

This is a more normal weather year, a more seasonal weather pattern this year than we had last year, but it's still been extremely cold across our territory. You've got to run a bunch of short trains. The terminals fill up. You can't get the air propagated through the normal train length. That's why we're running shorter trains and more of them. You see terminals will increase and so on. We'll get through all of that and spring is around the corner. And we expect to see a return to more normal service performance (inaudible).

BRIAN OSSENBECK: I sure hope it is. So just on coal, when you look at the export markets, and Met coal in particular, you could argue that we're coming down off of a cyclical peak from China's demand. We have, as you mentioned, excess supply in the market. FX clearly is not helping the US producers, but the miners are still going to mine in the US.

So how do you think about the network's ability to match what's being given to you from the miners? Is there ability to scale down trains and crews and some of the fixed assets? How do you manage the remaining part of when we get to more sustainable level, wherever that is, for exports from the US?

JAMES SQUIRE: Managing true volatility in that particular business, export coal, is a challenge. And it has been a very volatile business. Over the years, volumes have been up and down a lot if you go back historically. The toggle we have is, of course, crews. We can modulate crews to shoot the current conditions. In terms of fixed assets, the toggle we have is our railcar fleet. We own many of the coal cars that we use in export and the export business.

We've been in the process of a multiyear replenishment program, coal car buying program. We have completely hit the brakes on that. We have ample cars. So we are able to react by at least deferring -- perhaps canceling -- future capital expenditures devoted to that fixed-asset network.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Okay. Then on domestic thermal coal, it certainly feels like utilities have switched a fair amount to gas at this point in time. There's certainly structural issues on whether or not they can continue to do that. But do you feel that has really hit bottom at this point, at least the maximum amount of pressure? I know that's again getting back to weather, so that's the end of the first question.

The second, more longer term, there has been, with the emission controls and the ability to burn higher sulfur coal, there's been a bigger demand from at least the southeastern utilities to go into the interior basins, so the ILB and the PRB. Is that an area that you think Norfolk would look at expanding?

I know you have those Mid-Continent route with CN. So maybe you can just elaborate on where you see the short-term pressures ending and if there is room to grow, at least change the footprint in domestic coal, domestic thermal.

JAMES SQUIRE: Okay. Let me tackle short-term demand again first. Absolutely, gas at below $3 per million cubic feet, that's going to pressure our utility [lines]. There is a limit, however, and I would emphasize the point you made about structure. There is certainly a structural limit on how much gas our utility customers can burn.

And so we are going to ship coal to our utility customers this year. It's a question of how much and how much flexibility they have. At some point, they run out of gas-powered generation and they take coal. So certainly, there is a structural bottom to what they can do with gas.

From the regulatory side, it's much more of a long-term story. We have seen some takeout of coal volumes, minimal though, due to regulatory impositions the last few years. And we're calling for really low-single-digit tonnage to come out of demand this year, thanks to additional environmental regulations. Longer term, carbon regulation is certainly a question mark.

The pace of proposals seems to have slackened a little bit there and our utility franchise may be given a bit more time to adapt to whatever comes out in final form. But that's certainly a consideration for the franchise long term as well.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Right.

JAMES SQUIRE: Oh, you mentioned the basins.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Yes, (inaudible) sulfur.

JAMES SQUIRE: Certainly, the Illinois Basin is becoming an increasingly important source of coal for us and for our utility customers. And we do expect to see growth in ILB coals and PRB coals relative to [CAP and NAP]. [CAP] is particularly challenged from a cost standpoint. [NAP] is in a bit better shape. ILB and PRB are probably more of the future.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Right. I guess that would also help you on the coal-gas switching if they have a lower switching threshold versus gas.

JAMES SQUIRE: Sure.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: So I just want to ask you one question on auto because clearly, that's a big part of the business. What we've seen in the last couple of years or so is really a build of more penetration for specifically aluminum for light-weighting as we get back into the theme of more regulatory standards on fuel economy. So I was just curious because you do serve some of the larger plants that are involved in the big F-150 switchover.

I was just curious how that's -- how you see that affecting the network, if we start to move in that direction more and more. This is a giant step in that direction with the biggest -- the best-selling vehicle going -- a significant amount of aluminum. But has that affected the way you service those supply chains right now? And do you think that would be something that could really change the game a little bit if this were to be a longer term trend? And if so, how would you prepare for that?

JAMES SQUIRE: Ford, as you alluded, has made a bold gambit in using more aluminum in the F-150, which we haul for Ford, as you know. And it's going to be a terrific product for Ford and the consumer driven by CAFE standards and the need to increase fuel economy through lighter weight materials. Don't view it as a paradigm shift really for the auto industry or for us; for us because we participate in the aluminum supply chain as well.

And in addition, other manufacturers, steel manufacturers, are coming out with very lightweight steel materials that will, in some cases, be substituted for aluminum by other manufacturers. So net-net, it could have a modest impact on rail volumes, but I mean very, very modest in our case. We have large metals in the construction franchise, including some aluminum products and a lot of steel, including lightweight product as well.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Okay. We've got a full room here, so let's see if there's any questions from the floor. (Conference Instructions).

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Good morning. A quick question on oil trains -- have yourself or the industry done anything to improve the safety on these oil trains' speed or any other initiatives?

JAMES SQUIRE: Sure, absolutely. The question relates to crude by rail shipments and the industry's efforts to improve safety. We at Norfolk Southernand the industry have long been supporters of a better, safer tank car. So even predating the current proceeding at the Pipeline Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, we have been advocating for a more robust, crash-worthy, safer tank car.

And so the FIMSA, the regulatory agency, is set to come out with new regulations, we think in May of this year. We're all waiting anxiously for those regulations and we will, of course, abide by them and support them.

A couple of the key enhancements include a thermal blanket, a ceramic lap inside the tank car, which serves to protect a product if other tank cars are compromised. It extends the time that that product can remain safely in the tank car without collateral explosions. So that's one of the key features and there are some other enhancements.

In terms of operating practices, we voluntary slowed down, so we're operating at 40 miles per hour in high-threat urban areas. That's in accordance with the government's views on that as well. We have increased inspections of rail throughout our networks, particularly in corridors handling crude by rail and other hazardous commodities.

We're utilizing distributed power and telemetry devices in the trains that handle those commodities to enhance braking capability. So a whole host of measures to improve safety trends [in] crude by rail.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Looking out over the longer term, you quickly mentioned the clean power plan. Could you just go into a little bit more detail? Do you think that could be another step-change for coal volumes going down?

And how are you looking at CapEx with regard to coal and just the uncertainty about which plants could be closing? It's really not going to matter whether it's almost Appalachian coal or West Coast coal. It's just coal closing, period, so --

JAMES SQUIRE: Not to dodge the question about the effect of carbon regulation, but it's just too soon to tell. It's too conceptual and too far into the future to really be able to map confidently the impact of that on utility coal consumption, I believe. But we're certainly going to keep a close eye on it. And I flagged it earlier as a risk factor in the coal area, utility coal area.

Let's see, the second part of your question --

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: CapEx.

JAMES SQUIRE: -- had to do with CapEx, right. So there's not a lot of ongoing CapEx that's dedicated to our coal franchise to begin with. The big ticket item was the coal cars, and as I said, that's variable. And we've in fact stopped buying coal cars and we're in an attrition mode in terms of our own coal car fleet.

Longer term, there's a question about the franchise and the coal fields. We have an extensive track network in central Appalachia and northern Appalachia. The issue there is you've got a mine here, a mine there, tracks serving each. Coal mines, as you probably know, never really close. They just go quiet for a while and then they can be brought back. So it's a tough call to close a network or close tracks that run to these mines. With that said, if volume drops off, we'll look at rationalizing the track network along with the other assets we have in that franchise.

The one area where we might actually invest more in the coal business is in serving the Illinois Basin origins. There's a need for gathering facilities and some additional track structure in the ILB because that's not a region we have hauled coal from for very long. But that would not be material CapEx.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Just [pay-backing] on the crude by rail question, if the FIMSA regulation goes through, as you're expecting, how large do you expect the financial impact to be? My understanding is that everybody is going to feel it a little bit and you'll be able to pass some through. But you may have to carry some of it.

JAMES SQUIRE: It obviously depends on what the regulations prescribe. The gist of the regulations, as proposed, has to do with tank car safety enhancements, as I mentioned. We don't own the tank cars, so we would not be making the investments in those tank car enhancements.

How that could flow through to rates, I can't say right now, but one way or another, the supply chain picks up the additional cost and some of it is passed on to the customer of course, hopefully all of it, if you're the supply chain.

Other investments associated with the regulations, there's a question out there right now about electronically controlled pneumatic brakes. That's a technology that has been discussed in the FIMSA proceeding. The industry -- and there is some concern that FIMSA will require ECP brakes in all trains hauling crude by rail and perhaps other hazardous commodities.

We've actually experimented quite a bit with ECP brakes on our railroad. I think we're probably the furthest along in introducing ECP brakes into [revenue] service on Norfolk Southernof anyone. And what we've learned from that is it's tricky technologically. Like any big tech investment, it takes longer to bear fruit than you think.

When you start on it, you've got to keep the equipment together because you have to have [all the] cars in ECP service, so equipped as most of the locomotives will be equipped for ECP. So it creates operational complexity. We don't believe that the benefits of an ECP mandate for crude by rail would be worth it, given the benefits. So the industry has opposed that. We'll have to see what the government comes out with.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Okay.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Okay. Jim, just to bring it back to the higher level network perspective, you mentioned the second half 20145 service improvements. So can you just give us a sense of where that could be if you're looking at 2012, 2013 levels and how fast do you expect the network to get there?

JAMES SQUIRE: Of course, the metrics that we all look at, the public metrics, relate to terminal dwell and the system average train speed. Let me just digress on that for just a minute and tell you what we're seeing now and how we interpret the latest data there.

The good news is velocity is still tracking about a mile per hour better than at the trough last year. So for us, that's roughly 20 miles an hour as average network velocity versus 19 miles per hour in November of last year, which was the service trough. We've been able to hang on. We did a reset; velocity picked back up. It slipped some, but we're still better than we were last year.

Terminal dwell is the other key metric. Average terminal dwell in the most recent week was around 30 hours. That's about where it was last November. So unlike with velocity, where we've been able to hold onto the improvements, terminal dwell has risen to about the level where it was at the trough.

So what's going on? The story these metrics tell us really is one of fluidity on the network. The main lines are fluid, are open. Once the trains get out of the terminal, they proceed to destination in a relatively timely way. Now, long term, we're certainly looking to get back to that 2012, 2013 velocity level of more like 23 miles per hour on average. We think that'll happen in the second half.

The terminals, however, are very full and thus, the elevated terminal dwell right now. And that's because of the weather. When it gets this cold, you have to run a lot of short trains. You cannot propagate the air through the brake system and therefore, you have to run shorter trains, more trains, more trains in the terminals waiting for power.

And the other issue is the power. When it's cold, locomotives break. They don't like very cold, snowy weather, particularly DC locomotives. And so we see our bad orders, our shop locomotives spike this time of year; it always happens and that just detracts from the overall power equation. With that said, we have plenty of locomotives, but we are not out there --

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Do you feel good about --

JAMES SQUIRE: We have plenty of locomotives and when the velocity picks back up and the weather improves, we'll be putting locomotives in storage.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Okay. So --

JAMES SQUIRE: Yes, we expect to see service metrics rebound right back to that 2012, 2013 level, we think, in the second half.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Okay. Then just real quickly, 1 mile per hour better in speed. Do you have a rough estimate of how many locomotives you can take off the network when you hit that target?

JAMES SQUIRE: Right, so we think about that in terms of locomotives that we can put into storage --

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Right.

JAMES SQUIRE: -- as velocity improves. 100, give or take, per mile per hour is probably a reasonable estimate. So we'd be looking at putting a couple of hundred into storage, we think, as velocity rebounds to that 22, 23 miles per hour average system velocity.

Let me just say one other thing on crews. We had a lot of crew shortages last year. Crews are in much, much better shape right now. We on-boarded 400 conductors in the fourth quarter and we're feeling pretty robust right now in terms of the crew base. We'll continue to hire, but trains held for crews are way down.

This is not a time of year when we typically feel pressure from crew shortages because people don't take vacations in March or February usually. But so seasonally, this is a good time for crews anyway, but we're feeling very good about the crew situation. I think all of the pieces are in place for much better service performance come spring.

BRIAN OSSENBECK: Okay. It's a good place to end. Thank you very much, Jim, for your time.

JAMES SQUIRE: Okay. Thank you.
